events.title: IBM PC Project
events.detail: IBM decided to form a personal computer division the Entry Level Systems and launched 'Project Chess' to develop what would become the IBM PC.

events.title: Microsoft Secures IBM Contract
events.detail: Microsoft secured a contract with IBM to supply a CP/M operating system for IBM's upcoming personal computer.

events.title: Xerox Star Commercial Failure
events.detail: Despite pioneering many GUI concepts, the Xerox Star was prohibitively expensive ($16,595, equivalent to $57,000 in 2024) and failed to achieve significant market adoption.

events.title: IBM PC
events.detail: The IBM 5150 model was released, featuring an Intel 8088 CPU and MS-DOS.

events.title: Compaq Founded
events.detail: Compaq was founded, focusing on manufacturing IBM PC compatibles.

events.title: Apple Lisa / GUI
events.detail: Apple released the Lisa, the first commercial personal computer with a graphical user interface, priced at $9,995 and targeting business users.

events.title: Compaq Portable PC
events.detail: Compaq introduced the Compaq Portable, the first successful IBM PC-compatible portable computer, helping the company achieve record first-year sales.

events.title: Osborne Effect Causes Bankruptcy
events.detail: Osborne Computer Corporation announced an upcoming model prematurely, causing a collapse in current sales and leading to bankruptcy within a year.

events.title: Apple Macintosh
events.detail: Apple introduced the Macintosh with its famous '1984' Super Bowl commercial, bringing the graphical user interface to the mass market at $2,495.

events.title: Dell Computer Founded
events.detail: Michael Dell founded PC's Limited (later Dell Computer), selling IBM PC-compatible computers built from stock components from his college dorm room.

events.title: Apple Lisa Discontinued
events.detail: Apple discontinued the Lisa after poor sales, renaming remaining inventory as Macintosh XL and focusing resources on the more successful Macintosh line.

events.title: Windows 1.0
events.detail: Microsoft released Windows 1.0, the first version of its graphical operating environment.

events.title: Netscape Founded
events.detail: Jim Clark and Marc Andreessen founded Mosaic Communications Corporation (later renamed Netscape), developing the first widely popular web browser.

events.title: Microsoft Internet Explorer
events.detail: Microsoft released Internet Explorer 1.0, based on Spyglass Mosaic, beginning what would become known as the 'browser wars' with Netscape.

events.title: Netscape Browser
events.detail: Netscape released Mosaic Netscape 0.9, its first web browser, which would quickly capture 75% of the browser market within just four months.

events.title: Amazon Founded
events.detail: The e-commerce site Amazon.com, founded by Jeff Bezos, began operations.

events.title: eBay Founded
events.detail: eBay, an online auction platform, was founded, revolutionizing consumer-to-consumer sales.

events.title: Hotmail
events.detail: The free webmail service Hotmail was launched, quickly becoming popular worldwide.

events.title: PHP
events.detail: PHP 2.0 was released as an open-source scripting language designed for web development, which would become one of the most widely used server-side programming languages.

events.title: Mozilla
events.detail: Netscape publicly released the source code for its Navigator browser and established the Mozilla Organization, creating one of the most significant open-source projects in internet history and eventually leading to Firefox.

events.title: Google Search
events.detail: Google launched its search engine, changing internet information retrieval.

events.title: Napster
events.detail: Digital music revolution was sparked by Napster, a pioneering peer-to-peer file sharing service focused on music.

events.title: Dot-Com Bubble Peak
events.detail: The NASDAQ Composite index reached its peak at 5,048.62, more than double its value from a year before, marking the height of the dot-com bubble.

events.title: Black Friday
events.detail: The NASDAQ fell 9% in a single day, ending a week where it had declined 25%, marking the acceleration of the dot-com crash.

events.title: Boo.com Liquidation
events.detail: The high-profile online fashion retailer burned through over $100 million in just six months due to poor site design, over-ambitious expansion, and the dot-com crash.

events.title: Pets.com Collapse
events.detail: The online pet supply retailer Pets.com collapsed due to overexpansion and an unsustainable business model, symbolizing the burst of the dot-com bubble.

events.title: iPhone
events.detail: Apple's first iPhone was officially announced at Macworld.

events.title: iPhone On Sale
events.detail: The first-generation iPhone went on sale in the US, sparking long queues among consumers.

events.title: App Store
events.detail: Apple launched the App Store, allowing third-party developers to create and distribute applications for the iPhone.

events.title: iPhone 3G
events.detail: Apple introduced the iPhone 3G, offering faster 3G data connectivity and integrated GPS, marking a significant evolution over the original iPhone.

events.title: Google Open-Sources Android
events.detail: Google officially made the entire Android operating system available under open source licenses and enabling manufacturers to freely modify and distribute Android.

events.title: BlackBerry Storm Failure
events.detail: RIM’s first touchscreen phone launched to negative reviews for its clickable screen and buggy software, tarnishing BlackBerry’s reputation.

events.title: Android Market
events.detail: Google launched the Android Market (later Google Play Store), providing a platform for distributing Android applications.

events.title: Palm Pre Failure
events.detail: Hailed initially as an iPhone contender, the Palm Pre ultimately suffered from limited app support and poor marketing, contributing to Palm’s later acquisition by HP.

events.title: Nokia N97
events.detail: Nokia N97 was considered Nokia's first response following the iPhone-led touchscreen smartphone trend.

events.title: Nexus One
events.detail: Google and HTC introduced the Nexus One, offering a pure Android experience that influenced future smartphone designs.

events.title: Samsung Galaxy S
events.detail: Samsung released the Galaxy S series, marking the rise of the Android ecosystem.

events.title: iPhone 4
events.detail: Apple unveiled the iPhone 4 at a special event, showcasing a new design with a Retina display, front-facing camera, and improved performance.

events.title: Microsoft Kin Discontinued
events.detail: Microsoft’s Kin line of social-focused phones was pulled off the market just 6 weeks after launch, becoming one of the shortest-lived smartphone product lines in history.

events.title: Windows Phone 7
events.detail: Microsoft released Windows Phone 7, its attempt to compete with iOS and Android in the smartphone market.

events.title: iPhone 4S & Siri
events.detail: Apple introduced the iPhone 4S with Siri, the first widely-used voice assistant on smartphones.

events.title: HTC First Failure
events.detail: HTC released the HTC First, a smartphone integrated with Facebook features, but it failed to gain traction in a competitive market.

events.title: iPhone 5S & Touch ID
events.detail: Apple announced the iPhone 5S featuring Touch ID, the first mainstream fingerprint authentication system on smartphones.

events.title: Tesla Open-Sources Patents
events.detail: Elon Musk announced Tesla would not pursue patent lawsuits against anyone using their technology 'in good faith', aiming to accelerate the advancement of electric vehicle technology.

events.title: Tesla Gigafactory
events.detail: Tesla and Panasonic started building the Gigafactory in Nevada, with the goal of mass-producing lithium-ion batteries to reduce battery costs and increase production capacity.

events.title: Apple Initiates Car Project
events.detail: Rumors began circulating that Apple had started developing an electric vehicle under a secret project code-named 'Project Titan', sparking widespread speculation about Apple's future in the automotive industry.

events.title: Tesla Model 3
events.detail: Tesla held a Model 3 launch event, leading to a surge in pre-orders with nearly 400,000 reservations within weeks, demonstrating massive consumer interest in affordable EVs.

events.title: Apple Car Project Discontinued
events.detail: Reports emerged that Apple was restructuring its car project, shifting focus from building a complete vehicle to developing advanced autonomous driving technology, resulting in significant layoffs.

events.title: Chevrolet Bolt EV
events.detail: Chevrolet launched the Bolt EV, one of the first affordable electric vehicles with a long range, marking a significant milestone in the mainstream adoption of EVs.

events.title: China Eases Foreign Ownership Restrictions
events.detail: China announced gradual elimination of foreign ownership limits in the automotive industry, particularly for new energy vehicle companies, allowing foreign manufacturers to establish wholly-owned factories in China.

events.title: Tesla Roadster to Space
events.detail: SpaceX's Falcon Heavy maiden flight carried Elon Musk's personal Tesla Roadster into heliocentric orbit, creating a spectacular marketing moment connecting Tesla's and SpaceX's visions for the future.

events.title: China's EV Subsidy Cuts
events.detail: China announced significant reductions to EV subsidies, requiring manufacturers to improve technology and reduce costs, accelerating industry consolidation.

events.title: Dyson EV Project Discontinued
events.detail: The UK-based tech giant abruptly ended its ambitious electric vehicle program due to high costs and viability concerns, despite significant investment and prototypes.

events.title: Tesla Shanghai Gigafactory Deliveries
events.detail: Tesla delivered its first China-made Model 3 vehicles from the new Shanghai Gigafactory, marking Tesla's first manufacturing facility outside the United States.

events.title: Nikola Motor Controversy
events.detail: Allegations of fraud and misleading investors severely damaged Nikola Motor's credibility, marking one of the biggest controversies in the EV sector.

events.title: GPT-3.5
events.detail: OpenAI released the GPT-3.5 text-davinci-002 API.

events.title: ChatGPT
events.detail: OpenAI launched ChatGPT.

events.title: Microsoft Invests OpenAI
events.detail: Microsoft announced a new multiyear investment in OpenAI, amounting to $10 billion. This investment valued OpenAI at approximately $29 billion.

events.title: Google Bard
events.detail: Google's initial launch of Bard was marred by inaccuracies and technical issues, leading to a swift pullback and major revisions.

events.title: GPT-4
events.detail: OpenAI introduced GPT-4 which continues to follow the scaling law.

events.title: Perplexity
events.detail: Perplexity launched an ai1-powered answer engine that combined the conversational abilities of LLMs with real-time web information to deliver sourced answers.

events.title: Meta Llama 2
events.detail: Meta released Llama 2 as an open-source model with 7B, 13B, and 70B parameter versions, advancing open-source AI capabilities and enabling wider access to powerful language models.

events.title: Claude 3.5
events.detail: Anthropic released Claude 3.5 Sonnet, which leads in programming capabilities and becomes a major player.

events.title: OpenAI o1
events.detail: OpenAI released o1-preview, 1st reasoning model.

events.title: Deepseek R1
events.detail: Deepseek released the first open-weights reasoning model.

events.title: Multimodal Debut
events.detail: A consortium of leading research labs jointly launches a multimodal generative AI platform. While enterprises adopt it quickly for various applications, high compute demands delay broader consumer uptake.

events.title: Security Flaw Recall
events.detail: A critical vulnerability in a widely used generative AI service triggers a mass recall, spurring public calls for stricter data privacy measures and robust AI governance.

events.title: Global Ethics Council
events.detail: International bodies, academia, and policymakers collaborate to establish unified standards for fairness and transparency in AI, though implementation hurdles slow widespread adoption.

events.title: Autonomous Reasoning
events.detail: A new generative AI agent demonstrates advanced planning and multi-step problem-solving in real-world tasks. Early adopters applaud efficiency gains, while critics call for clearer accountability.

events.title: Open-Source Overtakes
events.detail: An open-source generative AI project surpasses top proprietary systems on key benchmarks, fuelling community-driven innovation and prompting debates on licensing models.

events.title: Hardware Bottleneck
events.detail: Global shortages of advanced computing components force many AI developers to scale back or delay projects, prompting research into more efficient training strategies and specialized hardware.

events.title: Google Gemini Robotics
events.detail: Google released Gemini Robotics model.

events.title: Nvidia GR00T
events.detail: Nvidia released GR00T N1 model, the world's first open humanoid robot foundation model.

events.title: Robot Pilots Kick Off
events.detail: Research institutes and robotics companies begin small-scale pilots integrating generative AI with lightweight robots. Early tests show promise for automated assembly but face hardware cost challenges.

events.title: Household Robot Boom
events.detail: A surge in demand for domestic robots—ranging from cleaning assistants to basic caregiving—raises excitement among investors, though many early models suffer from software glitches.

events.title: Standards Alliance Stalls
events.detail: An international effort to unify AI and robotics standards struggles amid disagreements over data privacy rules, causing delays in cross-border deployments.

events.title: Humanoid Robots Enter Production
events.detail: Several manufacturers ramp up assembly lines for general-purpose humanoid robots. Pre-orders exceed forecasts, signaling strong commercial interest in programmable robotic solutions.

events.title: Big-Model Training Overruns
events.detail: A major project to unify visual, speech, and haptic data into one large AI model faces spiraling costs and technical setbacks, prompting some backers to reduce funding.

events.title: New AI Laws Introduced
events.detail: Regulators worldwide enact tougher rules on data usage and algorithmic transparency in autonomous robots, aiming to curb potential ethical issues and protect consumer rights.

events.title: Hospital Robot Rollout Paused
events.detail: Large hospital chains temporarily suspend the deployment of advanced care and surgery-assist robots due to safety concerns and unresolved legal liabilities.

events.title: Open Robot Dev Communities Thrive
events.detail: Open-source robotics projects flourish worldwide, leveraging cloud-based AI and standardized robotic hardware. New features and use cases emerge at an unprecedented pace.

events.title: Space Robot Missions Succeed
events.detail: Autonomous robots powered by advanced generative AI complete critical tasks on lunar outposts and in low Earth orbit, reducing reliance on human extravehicular activity.

events.title: Public Service Robots Face Probe
events.detail: Several cities temporarily suspend police and firefighting robot operations after reports of AI bias and technical malfunctions spark public outcry over accountability and ethics.

events.title: Social Companion Robot Unveiled
events.detail: A major consumer electronics brand releases a new generation of social companion robot featuring emotion recognition and conversational AI. Although consumers show high enthusiasm, privacy advocates raise concerns over the collection of biometric data.

events.title: Robot Act Gains Support
events.detail: The UN's 'Responsible AI & Robotics' framework wins broad global endorsement, aiming to unify regulations and ethical guidelines. However, some leading economies remain cautious about the framework’s core provisions.

events.title: Undersea Robotics Project Discontinued
events.detail: An international initiative to use robots for deep-sea mining is suspended following critical equipment failures, sparking intense debate among environmental groups about the marine ecosystem and project feasibility.

events.title: ‘Robot-First’ Factory Expansion
events.detail: Several major electronics manufacturers announce large-scale expansions of ‘robot-first’ factories, cutting human jobs and triggering a heated public discussion on job displacement and the possibility of universal basic income.

events.title: Google Gemini Robotics
events.detail: Google released Gemini Robotics model.

events.title: Nvidia GR00T
events.detail: Nvidia released GR00T N1 model, the world's first open humanoid robot foundation model.

events.title: Major Robotics Acquisition
events.detail: A leading tech company acquires a prominent robotics startup for over $10 billion, signaling consolidation in the robotics market similar to early smartphone industry consolidation.

events.title: Robotics App Marketplace
events.detail: Launch of the first major marketplace for robot applications, allowing third-party developers to create and distribute software for consumer and industrial robots, similar to how smartphone app stores revolutionized mobile computing.

events.title: Generative AI Bubble Burst
events.detail: Following years of overinvestment and unrealistic expectations, a significant market correction occurs in the generative AI sector, with numerous startups failing and valuations dropping dramatically, similar to the dot-com crash of 2000.

events.title: Consumer Robot Failure
events.detail: A highly anticipated consumer robot product from a major company fails spectacularly due to reliability issues, privacy concerns, and limited functionality, echoing early smartphone failures like the BlackBerry Storm or Microsoft Kin.

events.title: Open Robot Foundation
events.detail: Major technology companies establish an open foundation for robotics development, sharing patents and standardizing interfaces to accelerate industry growth, similar to how Android was open-sourced or Tesla shared EV patents.

events.title: Multi-Modal AGI Breakthrough
events.detail: A significant breakthrough in multi-modal AI enables robots to understand and respond to complex environments with human-like comprehension, marking a milestone similar to the introduction of revolutionary features like touchscreens or Siri in the smartphone era.

events.title: AI Safety Incident
events.detail: A high-profile incident involving an AI system making harmful decisions leads to increased regulatory scrutiny and a temporary slowdown in AI deployment, similar to how manufacturing controversies affected the EV industry.

events.title: Robotics Subsidy Programs
events.detail: Several countries announce major subsidy programs for domestic robotics manufacturing and AI development, similar to how governments subsidized electric vehicle adoption to encourage economic growth and technological sovereignty.

events.title: Robotics Manufacturing Crisis
events.detail: Supply chain issues and component shortages cause a major crisis in robotics manufacturing, delaying deliveries and increasing prices, similar to challenges faced during early smartphone mass production.

events.title: Trillion-Dollar Robot Company
events.detail: The first robotics company reaches a trillion-dollar market valuation, cementing the industry's economic importance similar to how smartphone makers and internet companies achieved unprecedented valuations in previous tech waves.

connections.reason: Leading companies in the industry attempted to follow the latest trend but failed
Leading companies in the industry attempted to follow the latest trend but failed
Tech giants leverage their strengths in other technologies to gain an early foothold in emerging markets
Tech giants leverage their strengths in other technologies to gain an early foothold in emerging markets
Strategic software partnership defining an era
Market correction after period of exuberance
